channel.title: Server question
channel.description:
What amount of bandwidth and processing power is approximately required for an authoritative server using state synchronization and RPC's for processing data for lets say 100, 200, 500 and 1000 users.
And how much does that cost.

item.title: Server question
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

Ok, well thanks for all the help.

Read full topic

item.title: Server question
item.dc:creator: @ripzone Triton
item.description:
@ripzone wrote:

MistaBigBoss:

Actually, ever heard of WoW private servers, they are pretty much the same as the real ones.

Yes. And I’ve actually read the source of one implementation (MaNGOS). Now, that does not mean I know it fully well to estimate the network usage.

Thing is, it depends on so many factors that there is just no reliable answer. Also Unity uses RakNet internally, which sends data in UDP and has it’s own RPC and replication system. So if you use it you also have to factor for its own overhead.

Read full topic

item.title: Server question
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

I’m not sure how Unity deals with synchronization, you might want to write your own protocol if it sends unnecessary stuff…

Read full topic

item.title: Server question
item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

It guess it would depend on how bad you are at development & design. So in your case, I would say you’ll end up needing at least the Watson super computer and the equivalent amount of bandwidth that Chicago uses in a year.

In all unasshole seriousness, so many factors go into that, that I don’t think anyone here could tell you what you would need.

Read full topic

item.title: Server question
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

[quote=“Triton, post:4, topic:414583”]Did you even read what I just said? It depends on the protocol and I doubt any of us here are familiar with all the details of how the WoW protocol works. Also how would we know the processing power you need? Obviously depends on how much your particular game needs. If you can’t calculate this, or even know where to start, then it means you are not ready to make a game this scale.[/quote]Actually, ever heard of WoW private servers, they are pretty much the same as the real ones.
Well I’m not a networking guru but I know how it works in general and I’ll be using Unity’s networking protocols for handling the multiplayer.
There isn’t really that much difference in different protocols, the most important part of it is how you use it.
Let’s say you have a FPS game, where the user gives input, and the server processes all the data for movement, rotation, shooting, maybe even physics,… and then gives that information back to the client for updating it’s status. And it has to do this for about 100, 200, 400, 500 or 1000 players simultaneously. I understand that the protocol matters, but imagine if were to take the best possible protocol for doing this.

Read full topic

item.title: Server question
item.dc:creator: @ripzone Triton
item.description:
@ripzone wrote:

Did you even read what I just said? It depends on the protocol and I doubt any of us here are familiar with all the details of how the WoW protocol works. Also how would we know the processing power you need? Obviously depends on how much your particular game needs. If you can’t calculate this, or even know where to start, then it means you are not ready to make a game this scale.

Read full topic

item.title: Server question
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

[quote=“Triton, post:2, topic:414583”]Depends on the application, generality of the protocol and encoding features. Only you can know that.[/quote]Ok, then lets take an example, imagine a WoW server that is limited to the above mentioned amount of players.

Read full topic
